Chillicothe City School District administration and BOE have worked diligently this summer to create educational opportunities that will safely meet the needs of students, faculty, and families in Chillicothe. On July 14th the team met with the Ross County Health Department and Chillicothe Mayor Luke Feeney to review our back to school plans and received full approval from RCHD to reopen with instruction happening in-person five days a week for our students. Students who are returning to classrooms will be expected to comply with the safe return to school plans [wearing a mask, safe distancing, frequent hand washing], while families who are interested in continuing with a virtual option have until Friday, July 24th to register for those opportunities. CIS and CPS parents should communicate through Class Dojo and make sure to check there often for updates.

We're looking forward to having our Cavaliers back beginning August 10th!

#CavalierNation families:
Due to the increased number of students and staff being diagnosed with the flu, and in consultation with the Health Department I will be closing school on Friday, January 31st and Monday, February 3rd. All athletic and extracurricular events scheduled for Friday through Monday will be cancelled, this includes scheduled practice times. In addition, Latchkey will be closed at all locations, I apologize for this inconvenience, but in order to apply the incubation period of four days everything must be closed. The buildings will be thoroughly disinfected during this time, and I ask that if you child is ill on Tuesday morning please don't send them to school. I appreciate your patience during this time.
Sincerely,
Debbie Swinehart
Superintendent
Chillicothe City Schools

The Homeland Credit Union Cavalier Athletic Center will be closed during this period also: beginning January 31st and will reopen on February 4th.

CCSD Parents/Guardians: If your child is experiencing flu symptoms (fever over 100, chills, headache and muscle/body aches, cough, sore throat, runny/stuffy nose, vomiting, and diarrhea), please keep your child home until they are at least 24 hours free of symptoms (without medication). (It is also important to keep your child away from public/crowded places while they have symptoms). It is recommended to consult your doctor for Influenza screening (medications may be available to help decrease the severity and duration of the flu).

We had our buildings thoroughly cleaned over the weekend in an effort to reduce our students exposure to any flu germs while at school. Thank you for your assistance in keeping our students healthy and if you have questions or concerns please don't hesitate to contact your building principal or school nurse.
